title: 113_hr4467
content: The Act may be cited as the "Best Return on America's Investment Now Act" or the "BRAIN Act." It includes provisions for immigrant visas for certain advanced STEM graduates. The "Best Return on America's Investment Now Act" or the "BRAIN Act" includes provisions for immigrant visas for advanced STEM graduates holding doctorate degrees from U.S. institutions in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. Visas will be allocated to qualified immigrants meeting specific criteria. The "BRAIN Act" allows advanced STEM graduates with U.S. doctorate degrees in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics to pursue correspondence or distance education in the United States. Definitions for terms like distance education and fields of science are provided within the Act. The "BRAIN Act" allows STEM graduates with U.S. doctorate degrees to pursue distance education at eligible institutions classified as doctorate-granting universities with high research activity. The procedure for granting immigrant status under the Act is amended to expedite processing of petitions for alien beneficiaries qualifying under specific sections. The "BRAIN Act" expedites processing of immigrant petitions for alien beneficiaries under specific sections. The Secretary must adjudicate the petition within 30 days of receiving additional information or documentation. If the petition does not meet standards, the petitioner will be notified within 30 days of filing for resubmission. Section 203(b)(3)(A) of the Act is amended to change the percentage for Skilled Workers, Professionals, and Other Workers. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the National Science Foundation's use of classification authority. The amendments made by this section will be effective on October 1, 2014, and will apply to fiscal years starting on or after that date. The Secretary of Homeland Security can still accept petitions relating to alien beneficiaries before the effective date. SEC. 3. NUMERICAL LIMITATION TO ANY SINGLE FOREIGN STATE. Amendments are made to sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding employment-based immigrants and countries at ceiling. Amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding employment-based immigrants and countries at ceiling will take effect on October 1, 2014, applying to fiscal years starting on or after that date. SEC. 4. PERMANENT PRIORITY DATES. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to establish permanent priority dates for employment-based petitions. The priority date will be the date of filing with the Secretary of Homeland Security, unless preceded by a labor certification filing with the Secretary of Labor. The priority date can be retained for subsequent petitions. The amendment made by subsection (a) regarding self-petitions will be effective on October 1, 2014, applying to aliens with pending classification petitions on or after that date.
